newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: Space guru Arthur C. Clarke hails moon ice find.
newsitem.headline: Space guru Arthur C. Clarke hails moon ice find.

text.p: Space guru and author Arthur C. Clarke on Wednesday hailed the reported discovery of ice on the moon, saying it boosted the chances of establishing a permanently occupied moon base.
"It's extremely important and it's quite plausible," Clarke told Reuters in the capital of this Indian Ocean island.
He said the find made a permanently liveable moon base more likely -- ice can be used to provide water and oxygen -- but cautioned the discovery had not yet been confirmed.

U.S. scientists said in Washington on Tuesday a U.S. military spacecraft had found what appeared to be "a dirty, dirty lake" of ice on the moon that could one day help support a permanent human space base there.
U.S. Defence Department officials said the ice, found at the moon's south pole and which probably came from comets, could support a manned moon base for considerable time.
Clarke, 79, is the author of scores of novels and non-fiction books and creator of several documentaries and a long-time believer in the possibility of ice on the moon.

In 1954, 15 years before the first manned moon landing, he wrote: "It is not impossible that traces of water and gas, frozen solid, may exist deep down in lunar crevasses where the rays of the sun never penetrate."
In the past half century, scores of Clarke's predictions have come true, including his then-controversial 1945 outline of a network of geo-stationary communications satellites.
